title: Do I use the code "11 U.S.C. § 522" on Chapter 7 bankruptcy filing to exempt my Fidelity Rollover IRA?
question: I am filing for Chapter 7 bankruptcy in California. I am using only exemptions from the California System 2 exemptions list. I want to make sure that "11 U.S.C. § 522" is the correct code to use to exempt my Fidelity Rollover IRA account.
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Estates,Inherited Roth IRA and estate planning,Representing yourself
answers: The exemption you cite is federal, not state. CA has opted out of federal exemptions although there are some very specific exceptions where using federal is allowed. In either case a debtor cannot pick and choose from one exemption set for one item and go and pick from another set for another item. You get to choose a set and must use it for all the assets. Using correct set is vitally important when the debtor has some assets. Which exemption should I use type of question are potential grenades that are to be avoided unless one has been retained and an attorney client relationship has been formed. The best I can do is refer you to go to your local law library and pick up state specific bankruptcy law practice guide or see if local legal aid or bankruptcy court offers clinics or hire attorney to handle your case. Generally speaking of course, if there are in fact assets that need to be protected then it is worthwhile to have it done properly.

The short answer is no. the code you are citing is the federal code for exemptions: California has opted out of the federal exemptions and have their own sets. As everyone else has stated, you should speak to an experienced bankruptcy attorney to make sure you are protecting as many assets as you can. Most bankruptcy attorneys offer a free initial consultation, so go talk to one before a mistake is made.

Absolutely not! Exemptions under USC are only cited when someone can take federal exemptions. California does not use or allow federal exemptions, so you must cite California law. Hope this perspective helps!

If you have lived in California for 2 or more years or if you have lived in California for less than 2 years, but lived in California for the majority of the 180 days prior to the date that is 2 years prior to the filing of a petition for relief under the bankruptcy code, you must use one of the two California exemption schemes, one of which mirrors § 522(d) of the bankruptcy code, but is interpreted based upon California law instead of federal law.

If you are having to ask this question, that is a sign that you need to retain an experienced bankruptcy attorney instead of risking your assets by filing pro se. The best way to answer your question is to take advantage of a free initial consultation with an experienced bankruptcy attorney that handles chapter 7 and chapter 13 cases even if you think you need to file under chapter 7. Become educated on all the issues involved and related to your current economic situation, find out the advantages and disadvantages for filing under each chapter and use an attorney that can help you make the right decision for you. Most bankruptcy attorneys will meet with you at no charge for the initial appointment. You can use the Avvo "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this page to search for an attorney. You can look at each attorney’s profile to see what type of cases they handle and how Avvo ranks them.

No attorney can advise you specifically w/o knowing all your assets and if you lived in CA more than the last 2 years in a row. Other issues and facts can gravely affect your case too and as such I will point those out for you next so you understand the ONLY thing you want to do and do right is: employ an experienced bankruptcy attorney in CA!

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.
Exemption planning requires an in depth analysis into your financial situation. Please don't make the mistake of filing bankruptcy without a lawyer.

The decision to use either of the two exemption options cannot be made without understanding the full picture of your assets. More information is needed to give you useful advice. Click the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer". Some offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Take us up on it.
